abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated moderately
            satisfactory and sustainability is rated as likely.
            Institutional development is rated substantial. Both World
            Bank and Borrower performances are rated satisfactory.
            Project experience also suggests several lessons. First,
            strong monitoring and evaluation programs--clear and
            measurable indicators that are systematicaly collected over
            time--are essential to assess program impact and to improve
            the effectiveness of future interventions. Second, the
            socio-political environment has a strong influence on the
            effectiveness of national HIV/STI prevention programs. The
            Bank and partners can contribute /to strengthened political
            commitment by promoting dialogue with and among political
            leaders and other stakeholders, but this tends to be a
            long-term process. Third, decentralizing project activities
            to district level can improve local implementation, but
            needs to be accompanied by capacity building and
            institutional reforms to give districts greater autonomy
            over planning and budgeting. Finally projects planning to
            finance nongovernmental organizations/community activities
            need to develop clear modalities for doing so, and develop
            strategies to ensure that high-risk groups are targeted and
            that mechanisms are in place for monitoring, evaluation, and
            sharing lessons.

2054536.trustfund:
TF032962-AFRICA REGION - HEALTH &
            SOCIAL SECTOR,TF023044-PHRD-HIGHER EDUCATION
            DEVELOPMENT PROJ.,TF029146-PHRD-AIDS & HEALTH REFORM

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and the institutional development
            impact is substantial. Lessons highlight the need for clear
            project objectives at appraisal, when the development
            objectives depend on implementation of a broad program,
            enhanced by an appropriate design which should include both
            a project, and program monitoring criteria, including the
            joint review arrangements of the program by the cooperating
            partners. Such monitoring, and evaluation requires
            measurable, verifiable indicators for a fair assessment of
            project performance. Moreover, on addressing sexually
            transmitted diseases (STD), and HIV/AIDS epidemic, a shift
            from the narrow biomedical paradigm to a development one is
            required. Underlying the biological transmission of HIV, and
            STDs is a huge issue of social vulnerability, thus a
            programmatic approach is better suited to consolidate
            efforts, aimed at reducing, and mitigating the impact of the
            epidemic, focused on the underlying vulnerability issues.
            Greater efforts are also needed to involve both the private
            sector in the provision of services, and public-private
            partnerships collaborative efforts in sharing costs,
            emphasizing the promotion of an enabling sociopolitical
            environment. In addition, decentralized project
            implementation requires strong political commitment, and the
            decentralization of fiscal responsibility should be matched
            with authority, carefully supported by institutional
            capacity building. Finally, financial management should
            develop mechanisms for financing nongovernmental
            organizations, and, financial accounts, and reporting
            requirement systems should be recorded in a uniformed manner.

18155526.projn:
KE-Kenya Sexually Transmitted Infections
            Project -- P001333
18155526.theme: HIV/AIDS,Health system performance,Participation and civic engagement,Decentralization
18155526.trustfund:
TF029146-PHRD-AIDS & HEALTH REFORM,TF031095-AFRICA, POP.;HEALTH (KENYA,
            UGANDA, ETHIOPIA),UN007140-ASSES.OF THE SOCIAL COSTS OF STRUCT.ADJ.,TF032962-AFRICA REGION - HEALTH &
            SOCIAL SECTOR

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Sexually
            Transmitted Infections Project are to: strengtehen
            institutional capacity at the national and district levels
            to design, implement, monitor and evaluate interventions; to
            promote preventive measures to reduce the risks of sexually
            transmitted infection (STI) transmission; and to enhance
            both health sector and community provision of physical and
            psychological care and develop strategies to mitigate the
            socioeconomic consequences. The medium term plan identifies
            the following strategies and components to address these
            objectives: 1) prevention of sexual transmission of HIV
            through syndromic case management and the provision of
            standardized drug kits, promoting safer sexual behavior and
            promoting and providing condoms through primary level health
            facilities; 2) prevention of transmission through blood and
            blood products; 3) mitigation of socioeconomic impact by the
            treatment of turberculosis, providing drugs for
            opportunistic infections and protective supplies for
            government and non-government district health facilities and
            training health provider staff, and supporting district
            based nongovernmental and Community Based Organizations
            (CBO) home-based health care and counseling for HIV/AIDS
            patients; 4) epidemiology and surveillance; 5) coordination
            of research; and 6) management and coordination of a
            multi-sectoral AIDS control program.
